Message.Msg: I like your thinking Chance_Pocketwatch. I am hoping to get 40-50 years out of my DRIPs prior to retirement. Barring an unlikely catastrophe, KO will continue to pay out well for many more years. Balanced dividend income is my choice option during retirement.

Message.Title: 100 ko in 1956
Message.Msg: my father gave me 100 ko in 1956 as a graduation present. have not sold it and re invested all div. guess how many shares do i have know?
A nice gift. And also it kept on giving. Without looking, would have to assume more than 20k shares, probably a lot more.
Zero. You cashed it all in to buy hot dogs & beer. And then you were thirsty, so had to borrow money to buy a Coke.

Well of course everything is speculative, but it terms of risk/reward KO is historically proven. It's good to see a young person that plans for the future beyond the next tweet. I made a deal with my friends 17 year old daughter, where I transfered a share of AEP to her as a DRIP. I told her if you answer 4 questions, I'll give you a drip share of XOM, then 4 more questions and I'll add a KO drip share. The questions were like: what does price to earnings mean? What is AEP p/e. The intent was to give her a little smarts about investing, but she totally blew it off. So basically, I was offering her $88+ for answering 4 questions. Her school doesn't pay her anything to study, so how is she supposed to get an education. Around the time my parents got me involved in drips, my grandmother gave me some of her baseball cards and she loved Ty Cobb. As I began to research Ty Cobb, I found out how he made lots of money being invested in KO, which became my first interest in the company.
Time to buy was in 2009...that was too easy. Now it is priced in.

Message.Title: Advertizing MB?
Message.Msg: Is this MB mainly for advertising other finance services or what?
Yes. How many do you have?
What were you graduating from?? You would have been 8 years old in 1956 if you are 64 as you profile states. Sounds like a bunch of bull to me!!!

Message.Title: glad to see KO move up
Message.Msg: maybe will see some movement towards target price. Don't get me wrong this is a very slow growth stock. Question for long time holders. How does this stock react during the (and I can't believe how time flies) holiday season.

Message.Title: Forward P/E over 18?
Message.Msg: Is it because of their dividend history + income seekers finding something other than treasuries for their money? This feels too expensive here.

Message.Title: HAD COKE SINCE JULY 29,1972
Message.Msg: Dad gave us 50 shares of coke on july 29,1972 the day we were married, we still have the 50 and a lot more since then have bought many shares over the 40 years, i can't remember how many split's?, reinvested div over this time, and have seen coke in bad and good times, the ceo that took over about 2005 i think really made coke go! Oh and by the way we are still married after 40 years, and i guess one day our kids will get the coke shares, hope it is not to soon! Great company & you have a great day!

Message.Title: Cisco vs Coke, a comparison
Message.Msg: TheBigStock has a comparison of Cisco and Coke in terms of valuation. http://thebigstock.com/2012/08/16/cisco-systems-vs-coca-cola/
